Merriken And Pike, Rival
Captains, Will Oppose
Each Other
By STANLEY E. BLUMBERG

Opposition of a decidedly higher
caliber will be encountered by the
Hopkins stickmen tomorrow afternoon at Homewood when they buck
up against Swarthmore College in
an attempt to secure their third
consecutive victory.
Swarthmore, tutored by Avery
Blake, former Mount Washington
player, has long been recognized as
one of the best lacrosse teams outside of Maryland, but was never
considered in the same category
with the leading Free State tens.
This year, however, the Garnet
seems to have reached a higher point
of perfection than ever before, as is
evidenced in the 7-4 trouncing it administered to St. John's last Saturday.
Defeat N. Y. U., Johnnies

The Pennsylvanians opened their
campaign against Mount Washington, and showed potential strength
while losing to the Hillmen by a 9-4
margin. They followed this up with
a sweeping victory over N. Y. 1.1.,
and then surprised even their most
ardent supporters by defeating St.
John's. The manner of their triumph left little to be desired, for
they combined clever passing and
accurate shooting on attack with
defensive
effective
consistently
work.
An interesting feature in connection with tomorrow's game lies in
the situation that the rival captains,
Lloyd Pike and Moke Merriken,
were formerly teammates when they
attended Friends School. The fact
that Merriken, from his position at
point, will be delegated to guard
Pike, who was leading intercolle( giate scorer last season, makes this
individual duel all the more intriguing.

penalty may be harsher because he
failed to confess.

Banquet To Be Held At Baltimore Country
Club
Isham Jones's orchestra, nationally known radio band, definitely
will appear at the junior Prom,
June 8, the opening event of June
Week, sponsored by the 1933 graduating class of the Johns Hopkins
University. The contract was
signed this week, John Henderson,
chairman of the Week; announced
today.
An orchestra for the Senior Ball,
to be held June 13, has not been
selected. It was revealed today that
Guy Lombardo's Royal Canadians,
who played at the 1931 Hopkins
Ball, will not be available due to
the fact the famous band has been
chosen to appear at the World's Fair
in Chicago in June. Negotiations
are under way now for Eddie Duchin, it was learned.
Annual Banquet

On the night preceding the climaxing affair of June Week, the
annual Senior Ball, the Senior Banquet will be held at the Baltimore
Country Club, Henderson has announced. The guests of honor are
expected to be Gov. Albert C.
Ritchie; Dr. Joseph S. Ames, president of the J. H. U.; Daniel Willard, president of the Hopkins board
of trustees; Dr. E. W. Berry, dean
of the College of Arts and Sciences
at Homewood; Dr. J. C. Smallwood, honorary president of the
Senior Class; Senator Millard Tydings, and Dr. Hugh H. Young.
The A.
Barton Cup will be
awarded to the most outstanding
senior, Henderson said. Following
the-banquet a dance will be held at
the B. C. C. The Townsmen, local
popular radio orchestra, will play.

polls being open from 12.30 to 1.30 p. m. Bill Triplett, Council
president for the current year, has announced that the two men receiving the highest number of votes in this primary will be the final candidates in the election to be held on Thursday, May 4. The names of
the pair will not be made known until that date.
The following quotation is from the Student Council constitution,
Article IV, Section 1, governing elections:
. . . The election . . . shall be by signed ballot.
The election shall be declared non-valid unless taken part in
by at least a majority of the undergraduate body."
The latest figure for the accurate enrollment of the undergraduate
department as determined by the Registrar's Office is 899. According
to the terms of the constitution, then, at least 450 ballots must be cast.
Several men on the campus expressed their surprise at the small
number of nominees. It is hoped that many more will be put forth
next Thursday when nominations will reopen.

Dr. Paul van Zeeland, Director
of the National Bank of Belgium,
Assistant-Director of the Bank for
International Settlements at Basel,
and Director of the Louvain Institute of Economics, will deliver a
series of lectures entitled "A European View, 1932" in Latrobe Hall,
at 5 p. m. all through next week and
part of the week following.
The aim of these addresses, it was
stated by J. V. A. MacMurray, Director of the Page School, is to present to Americans the opinions of
European economists on the world
economic situation. Through such
a presentation of his own views as
well as of those prevailing in Europe, Dr. van Zeeland hopes to
describe the role of the U. S. in the
total crisis and to insinuate the desirability and importance of this
country's taking a definite and clearly expressed stand on international
issues.

Practically the entire Physics Department of the Johns Hopkins University will attend the 184th regular
meeting of the American Physical
Society, to be held in Washington,
D. C., at the Bureau of Standards
on Thursday and Friday, April 27
and 28, and at the National Academy of Sciences, on Saturday, April
29th.
The schedule of papers for this
meeting includes three by members
of the faculty of Johns Hopkins.
On Friday morning at the Bureau
of Standards a paper by J. A. Bearden and C. H. Shaw of the Physics
Department of Johns Hopkins, will
be read on "Wave Lengths and
Shapes of the K Series Lines of
Copper, Nickel, Cobalt, Iron, and
Cromium.
In the afternoon Professor R. W.
Wood will read his paper on "Remarkable Optical Properties of the
Alkali Metals."

Tau Beta Pi, national honorary
engineering society, initiated five
juniors as new members at the assembly held yesterday.
Following the initiation ceremonies, Milton L. Regus, educational
director of the Rand-McNally and
Co., addressed the assembly on
"Modern Education or the Riddle of
Culture."
Names Men

The engineering honor group
elected to membership:
RICHARD BONDY KAUFMAN
PAUL LEVIN
HENRY STANGE ORTH
RAYMOND HENRY PLACK
WILLIAM ROGER SMALL, JR.
Noted Educator

Long associated with education,
Mr. Regus bases his observations
of the modern trends of schools on
both classroom experience and field
observation.
In his address, Mr. Regus stressed
the changes that have taken place in
educational methods since 1900. He
Pointed out that the modern school
"utilizes child nature but does not
become a victim of child whims."
In part his speech follows:
"Self-activity on the- part of the
learner and repetition with attention
are still the master keys of wisdom.
Changes are always taking place in
the learning processes and every
generation of boys and girls benefits from the improvement made in
instruction through the science of
education."
Requisites

Good scholarship, leadership,
adaptability, character, activities,
personality, and fellowship are
among the attributes considered in
the selection of men to the Maryland Alpha Chapter of Tau Beta Pi
One-fourth of the senior class is eligible for membership, while only
the upper eighth of the juniors may
be named to this honor.
Elections are held in the spring
and fall. Six seniors and two juniors were honored by this fraternity
last fall. William N. Myers, Albert C. Thomas, John A. Wachter,
William J. Wiseman and John T.
Keane were the seniors. The juniors were Philip B. Onderdonk and
John N. Terry.
Founded in 1885

Founded at Lehigh University in
1885, Tau Beta Pi was organized on
the Hopkins campus in 1919. Dr.
A. G. Christie, professor of mechanical engineering, was instrumental
in securing a chapter of the national
organization at the Hopkins. In the
60 chapters of the fraternity, there
are over 16,000 members.
Among the faculty members who
have been named to the Hopkins
chapter are Drs. John B. Whitehead, W. J. Huff, W. B. Kouwenhoven, J. C. W. Frazier, J. C. Hubbard, John H. Gregory, J. T.
Thompson and T. F. Hubbard.

H. Levin, M. Katz Chosen
To Head Honorary
Fraternity
Hyman Levin was elected president of the Johns Hopkins University chapter of Pi Delta Epsilon, national honorary collegiate journalistic fraternity.
Other officers
named are Mortimer Katz, vicepresident; Theodore Stern, secretary; and Paul Coburn, treasurer.
The fraternity, Levin stated, is
interested in the general improvement of the three campus publications but at the same time recognizes the individual right of each
publication to manage itself without interference. In the future it
also hopes, he said, to settle controversial measures deadlocking in the
various boards of control.
The fraternity has forwarded a
letter to Dean Berry advocating that
the Jay officers be given a chance,
financially etc., to make good.

Scholarship Committee

Selections are made each spring
by a committee of three men who
are selected from among the leaders in the chemical fields of the
state. Notification of the appointment is made on or before April 1.
The scholarship committee valuates the student's complete pervious
scholastic record and personal qualities as rated by his instructors.
Among the qualities considered are:
health, conduct, scholarship, enthusiasm, and faculty of observation.

Squire Reelected
To Presidency Of
Debating Society
Willen, Wiggall, And Bang Are
Selected For Other Executive Officers
At a recent meeting of the Debating Society, Charles Squire was
elected president; Abner Willen,
vice-president; Richard Wiggall,
business manager; and Fred Bang,
advertising manager.
The group intends to enlarge its
'activities next year by having more
debates and is planning discussions
before interested organizations such
as the Rotary Club, Kiwanis Club,
and others. A greater effort is to
be placed in obtaining interested audiences rather than large ones.
Forensic Union Planned

Squire and Wiggall are working
on forming a forensic union of the
universities of the eastern coast
which will include many of the larger schools. Every year teams from
these universities would compete
against each other seeking to carry
off the debating honors.
Two weeks ago the debating team
took a trip and met Pittsburgh,.Buffalo, and Niagara Universities. Debates, arranged with two other colleges, had to be cancelled owing to
unforeseen circumstances. Last
Tuesday a final meet was held with
Fordham University on "War
Debts", in which Blattner and
Young of Hopkins favored cancellation.

Well... here it is...already
whittled FOR you. Granger
Rough Cut is tobacco whittled right . . . that's one
reason why it burns so slow
and cool.
HEN we started to make Granger
Rough Cut we knew that fine tobacco burnt hot because it burnt so fast. It
kept your pipe hot. You could hardly
hold your pipe in your hand, it got so
hot at times.
Then we remembered that some folks
back yonder used to "whittle" their tobacco. So we made GRANGER just like
"whittle" tobacco — "Rough Cut." It
smokes cooler and lasts a lot longer. And
also, you'll find it never gums the pipe.
So far, so good. Now we wanted to sell
this tobacco for 10c. Good tobacco—right
process—cut right. It was a question of
how to do it for the price.
So we put GRANGER in a sensible soft
foil pouch instead ofan expensive package,
knowing that a man can't smoke a package.
We gave smokers this good GRANGER
tobacco in a common-sense pouch for 10c.
GRANGER has not been on sale very
long, but it has grown to be a popular
smoke. And there is this much about it
—we have yet to know of a man who
started to smoke it, who didn't keep on.
Folks seem to like it.

Captains, Will Oppose

By STANLEY E. BLUMBERG

Opposition of a decidedly higher
caliber will be encountered by the
Hopkins stickmen tomorrow afternoon at Homewood when they buck
up against Swarthmore College in
an attempt to secure their third
consecutive victory.
Swarthmore, tutored by Avery
Blake, former Mount Washington
player, has long been recognized as
one of the best lacrosse teams outside of Maryland, but was never
considered in the same category
with the leading Free State tens.
This year, however, the Garnet
seems to have reached a higher point
of perfection than ever before, as is
evidenced in the 7-4 trouncing it administered to St. John's last Saturday.
Defeat N. Y. U., Johnnies

The Pennsylvanians opened their
campaign against Mount Washington, and showed potential strength
while losing to the Hillmen by a 9-4
margin. They followed this up with
a sweeping victory over N. Y. 1.1.,
and then surprised even their most
ardent supporters by defeating St.
John's. The manner of their triumph left little to be desired, for
they combined clever passing and
accurate shooting on attack with
defensive
effective
consistently
work.
An interesting feature in connection with tomorrow's game lies in
the situation that the rival captains,
Lloyd Pike and Moke Merriken,
were formerly teammates when they
attended Friends School. The fact
that Merriken, from his position at
point, will be delegated to guard
Pike, who was leading intercolle( giate scorer last season, makes this
individual duel all the more intriguing.

Banquet To Be Held At Baltimore Country
Club
Isham Jones's orchestra, nationally known radio band, definitely
will appear at the junior Prom,
June 8, the opening event of June
Week, sponsored by the 1933 graduating class of the Johns Hopkins
University. The contract was
signed this week, John Henderson,
chairman of the Week; announced
today.
An orchestra for the Senior Ball,
to be held June 13, has not been
selected. It was revealed today that
Guy Lombardo's Royal Canadians,
who played at the 1931 Hopkins
Ball, will not be available due to
the fact the famous band has been
chosen to appear at the World's Fair
in Chicago in June. Negotiations
are under way now for Eddie Duchin, it was learned.
Annual Banquet

On the night preceding the climaxing affair of June Week, the
annual Senior Ball, the Senior Banquet will be held at the Baltimore
Country Club, Henderson has announced. The guests of honor are
expected to be Gov. Albert C.
Ritchie; Dr. Joseph S. Ames, president of the J. H. U.; Daniel Willard, president of the Hopkins board
of trustees; Dr. E. W. Berry, dean
of the College of Arts and Sciences
at Homewood; Dr. J. C. Smallwood, honorary president of the
Senior Class; Senator Millard Tydings, and Dr. Hugh H. Young.
The A.
Barton Cup will be
awarded to the most outstanding
senior, Henderson said. Following
the-banquet a dance will be held at
the B. C. C. The Townsmen, local
popular radio orchestra, will play.

Dr. Paul van Zeeland, Director
of the National Bank of Belgium,
Assistant-Director of the Bank for
International Settlements at Basel,
and Director of the Louvain Institute of Economics, will deliver a
series of lectures entitled "A European View, 1932" in Latrobe Hall,
at 5 p. m. all through next week and
part of the week following.
The aim of these addresses, it was
stated by J. V. A. MacMurray, Director of the Page School, is to present to Americans the opinions of
European economists on the world
economic situation. Through such
a presentation of his own views as
well as of those prevailing in Europe, Dr. van Zeeland hopes to
describe the role of the U. S. in the
total crisis and to insinuate the desirability and importance of this
country's taking a definite and clearly expressed stand on international
issues.

Tau Beta Pi, national honorary
engineering society, initiated five
juniors as new members at the assembly held yesterday.
Following the initiation ceremonies, Milton L. Regus, educational
director of the Rand-McNally and
Co., addressed the assembly on
"Modern Education or the Riddle of
Culture."
Names Men

The engineering honor group
elected to membership:
RICHARD BONDY KAUFMAN
PAUL LEVIN
HENRY STANGE ORTH
RAYMOND HENRY PLACK
WILLIAM ROGER SMALL, JR.
Noted Educator

Long associated with education,
Mr. Regus bases his observations
of the modern trends of schools on
both classroom experience and field
observation.
In his address, Mr. Regus stressed
the changes that have taken place in
educational methods since 1900. He
Pointed out that the modern school
"utilizes child nature but does not
become a victim of child whims."
In part his speech follows:
"Self-activity on the- part of the
learner and repetition with attention
are still the master keys of wisdom.
Changes are always taking place in
the learning processes and every
generation of boys and girls benefits from the improvement made in
instruction through the science of
education."
Requisites

Good scholarship, leadership,
adaptability, character, activities,
personality, and fellowship are
among the attributes considered in
the selection of men to the Maryland Alpha Chapter of Tau Beta Pi
One-fourth of the senior class is eligible for membership, while only
the upper eighth of the juniors may
be named to this honor.
Elections are held in the spring
and fall. Six seniors and two juniors were honored by this fraternity
last fall. William N. Myers, Albert C. Thomas, John A. Wachter,
William J. Wiseman and John T.
Keane were the seniors. The juniors were Philip B. Onderdonk and
John N. Terry.
Founded in 1885

Founded at Lehigh University in
1885, Tau Beta Pi was organized on
the Hopkins campus in 1919. Dr.
A. G. Christie, professor of mechanical engineering, was instrumental
in securing a chapter of the national
organization at the Hopkins. In the
60 chapters of the fraternity, there
are over 16,000 members.
Among the faculty members who
have been named to the Hopkins
chapter are Drs. John B. Whitehead, W. J. Huff, W. B. Kouwenhoven, J. C. W. Frazier, J. C. Hubbard, John H. Gregory, J. T.
Thompson and T. F. Hubbard.

H. Levin, M. Katz Chosen
To Head Honorary
Fraternity
Hyman Levin was elected president of the Johns Hopkins University chapter of Pi Delta Epsilon, national honorary collegiate journalistic fraternity.
Other officers
named are Mortimer Katz, vicepresident; Theodore Stern, secretary; and Paul Coburn, treasurer.
The fraternity, Levin stated, is
interested in the general improvement of the three campus publications but at the same time recognizes the individual right of each
publication to manage itself without interference. In the future it
also hopes, he said, to settle controversial measures deadlocking in the
various boards of control.
The fraternity has forwarded a
letter to Dean Berry advocating that
the Jay officers be given a chance,
financially etc., to make good.

April 17 will have to pay $23.50
instead of $20.00, which was the
original reduced fee.

Scholarship Committee

Selections are made each spring
by a committee of three men who
are selected from among the leaders in the chemical fields of the
state. Notification of the appointment is made on or before April 1.
The scholarship committee valuates the student's complete pervious
scholastic record and personal qualities as rated by his instructors.
Among the qualities considered are:
health, conduct, scholarship, enthusiasm, and faculty of observation.

Squire Reelected
To Presidency Of
Debating Society
Willen, Wiggall, And Bang Are
Selected For Other Executive Officers
At a recent meeting of the Debating Society, Charles Squire was
elected president; Abner Willen,
vice-president; Richard Wiggall,
business manager; and Fred Bang,
advertising manager.
The group intends to enlarge its
'activities next year by having more
debates and is planning discussions
before interested organizations such
as the Rotary Club, Kiwanis Club,
and others. A greater effort is to
be placed in obtaining interested audiences rather than large ones.
Forensic Union Planned

Squire and Wiggall are working
on forming a forensic union of the
universities of the eastern coast
which will include many of the larger schools. Every year teams from
these universities would compete
against each other seeking to carry
off the debating honors.
Two weeks ago the debating team
took a trip and met Pittsburgh,.Buffalo, and Niagara Universities. Debates, arranged with two other colleges, had to be cancelled owing to
unforeseen circumstances. Last
Tuesday a final meet was held with
Fordham University on "War
Debts", in which Blattner and
Young of Hopkins favored cancellation.

Well... here it is...already
whittled FOR you. Granger
Rough Cut is tobacco whittled right . . . that's one
reason why it burns so slow
and cool.
HEN we started to make Granger
Rough Cut we knew that fine tobacco burnt hot because it burnt so fast. It
kept your pipe hot. You could hardly
hold your pipe in your hand, it got so
hot at times.
Then we remembered that some folks
back yonder used to "whittle" their tobacco. So we made GRANGER just like
"whittle" tobacco — "Rough Cut." It
smokes cooler and lasts a lot longer. And
also, you'll find it never gums the pipe.
So far, so good. Now we wanted to sell
this tobacco for 10c. Good tobacco—right
process—cut right. It was a question of
how to do it for the price.
So we put GRANGER in a sensible soft
foil pouch instead ofan expensive package,
knowing that a man can't smoke a package.
We gave smokers this good GRANGER
tobacco in a common-sense pouch for 10c.
GRANGER has not been on sale very
long, but it has grown to be a popular
smoke. And there is this much about it
—we have yet to know of a man who
started to smoke it, who didn't keep on.
Folks seem to like it.
